head.title: Pulsed Laser Confinement of Single Atomic Catalysts on Carbon Nanotube Matrix for Enhanced Oxygen Evolution Reaction | ACS Nano

meta.content: Pulsed Laser Confinement of Single Atomic Catalysts on Carbon Nanotube Matrix for Enhanced Oxygen Evolution Reaction

The design of atomically dispersed single atom catalysts (SACs) must consider high metal-atom loading amount, effective confinement, and strong interactions with matrix, which can maximize their catalytic performance. Here reported is a promising method to synthesize SACs on highly conductive multiwall carbon nanotube (MWCNT) supports using pulsed laser confinement (PLC) process in liquid. Atomic cobalt (Co) and phosphorus (P) with a high loading density are homogeneously incorporated on the outer wall of the MWCNT (Co–P SAC MWCNT). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations in combination with systematic control experiments found that the incorporated Co and P adatoms act as an adsorption energy optimizer and a charge transfer promoter, respectively. Hence, favorable kinetics and thermodynamics in Co–P SAC MWCNT can be simultaneously achieved for water oxidation resulting in a superior catalytic performance than the benchmark RuO2 catalyst. Crucially, total processing time for assembling Co–P SAC MWCNT via PLC process is less than 60 min, shedding light on the promising practical applications of our SAC design strategy.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
The design of atomically dispersed single atom catalysts (SACs) must consider high metal-atom loading amount, effective confinement, and strong interactions with matrix, which can maximize their catalytic performance. Here reported is a promising method to synthesize SACs on highly conductive multiwall carbon nanotube (MWCNT) supports using pulsed laser confinement (PLC) process in liquid. Atomic cobalt (Co) and phosphorus (P) with a high loading density are homogeneously incorporated on the outer wall of the MWCNT (Co–P SAC MWCNT). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations in combination with systematic control experiments found that the incorporated Co and P adatoms act as an adsorption energy optimizer and a charge transfer promoter, respectively. Hence, favorable kinetics and thermodynamics in Co–P SAC MWCNT can be simultaneously achieved for water oxidation resulting in a superior catalytic performance than the benchmark RuO
2
catalyst. Crucially, total processing time for assembling Co–P SAC MWCNT via PLC process is less than 60 min, shedding light on the promising practical applications of our SAC design strategy.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

div.div:
With the potential to meet the global energy demand and reduced fossil fuel consumption, water splitting has been attracting the attention of researchers. One of the promising techniques of water splitting is electrochemical water splitting using electrolyzers.
(1,2)
However, a sluggish anodic reaction, oxygen evolution reaction (OER), suspends a practical application of an electrolyzer.
(3−5)
Therefore, the design of high-performance and low-cost materials for electrochemical water splitting is of high scientific as well as industrial significance.
(6,7)
Studies have attempted to develop non-noble metal based OER electrocatalysts with abundant catalytic sites for large-scale applications.
(8−11)
Recently, single-atom catalysts (SACs), consisting of confined solute atoms in metallic matrix, have been attracting wide attention owing to their high catalytic efficiency, high site homogeneity, and diverse options for solute and matrix materials. In addition, the interaction between the solute and matrix can modulate electronic configuration, further boosting catalytic performance.
(12−18)
Especially, D. Wang’s has been summarized the SACs derived from metal–organic framework (MOF)-based materials, which shows the enhanced OER performance by the single atom confinement.
(19)
Furthermore, W. Cheng and co-workers reported a W single atom anchored on N-doped carbon matrix by hydrothermal and pyrolysis strategy.
(20)
Y. Xue and co-workers found that Ni and Fe SACs can be obtained by an electrodeposition method.
(21)
In addition, H. Wei and co-workers also reported a simple method to synthesize Pt SACs by photochemical reduction of frozen H
2
PtCl
2
solution.
(22)

Although there have been some developments, the actual application of SAC-based materials in electrolyzers is currently unfeasible because of the lack of promising synthetic routes for inducing abundant and stable (i.e., no segregation) single metal atoms on the support.
(23)
To solve this issue, modification of the supports by introducing dopants, defects, or vacancies has been widely studied, but this adds costly processing and complexity. A major drawback of this method is the insufficient amount of single atoms attributable to the limited amount of inducible defects.
(15−17)
In addition to the number of active sites, physicochemical interactions between the single atoms and supports significantly affect the activity and stability of SACs.
(24−26)
The stable and efficient anchorage of single atoms on the supports can therefore provide a means to rationally design high-performance SACs. However, promising strategies for simultaneously securing abundant single catalytic atoms on the supports with robust physicochemical interactions have very rarely been reported. Hence, such strategies must be further explored.

Pulsed laser ablation (PLA) is a promising process for synthesizing functional nanomaterials.
(27,28)
PLA has various advantages because the process is chemically simple and clean without byproduct formations, has ultrafast processing time (i.e., highly cost-effective), and notably, has excellent down-sizing ability of nanomaterials, even up to the quantum scale with a very homogeneous distribution.
(29,30)
Furthermore, high energy induced by a pulsed laser within pico-second time intervals, followed by a rapid quenching process, generates strong physicochemical interactions at the interface of different starting materials.
(28)
The rapid quenching in PLA due to ultrashort energy intervals in liquids may effectively confine single atoms on the supports by suppressing the formation of nanoclusters, hereafter termed as the pulsed laser confinement (PLC) technique. Thus, PLC can offer a facile method for the synthesis of highly efficient SACs that fulfill the two aforementioned criteria. Moreover, compared to the wet-chemical methods, the pulsed laser process can substantially reduce the processing times and costs due to simple and environmentally-friendly process.
(31)
In addition, few studies have attempted to use pulsed laser, especially for synthesizing active OER electrocatalysts.

Here, we report a facile and effective PLC method for synthesizing Co and P SACs on a multiwall carbon nanotube (MWCNT) matrix (Co–P SAC MWCNT PLA). A rapid quenching effect during PLC enables successful confinements of Co and P single atoms on the surface of MWCNT matrix with a high doping level as well as strong physicochemical interactions. Aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) verified that the Co and P SACs are mainly incorporated on the outer shell of MWCNT. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations demonstrated that the synergetic effects of Co and P SACs can boost the electrocatalytic performance of Co–P SAC MWCNT PLA for OER. To the best of our knowledge, the synthesis of SACs on carbon-based materials using pulsed laser with excellent OER performance is very rare. Furthermore, the developed material engineering concept for SACs on carbon matrix through PLC is a facile and cost-effective method, which can be extended to other functional systems with a highly promising practical potential.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Co–P SAC MWCNT was synthesized via an ultrafast and environmentally-friendly PLC process. First, 1.5 g of cobalt nitrate (Co(NO
3
)
2
·6H
2
O), 30 mL of phosphoric acid, and 0.1 g of MWCNT were dissolved in 0.5 L of high purity ethanol (
Figure
1
a-i). Thereafter, pulsed laser with a wavelength of 355 nm (third harmonic) at a repetition rate of 10 Hz was irradiated to yield the as-prepared solution (
Figure
1
a-ii). After the PLC process was performed for 60 min, the precursors were transferred to the tubular structure of Co–P SAC MWCNT (
Figure
1
a-iii).
Figure S1
shows that the as-prepared Co–P SAC MWCNT via PLC well retains the tubular MWCNT structure. TEM was employed to study the structural as well as compositional characteristics of Co–P SAC MWCNT in detail. Low-resolution TEM images confirmed a well-defined tubular structure of Co–P SAC MWCNT (
Figure
1
b,c), in which any nano- or (sub)nanoparticles were not observed inside and outside the nanotube. The average diameter of the nanotube was approximately 30 nm. Fast Fourier transformation (FFT) patterns indicated a highly crystalline nature of Co–P SAC MWCNT (inset of
Figure
1
c).
Figure
1
d shows a high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of Co–P SAC MWCNT, which clearly shows the (002) lattice plane of CNT (JCPDS no. 01–0646) corresponding to the interplanar distance of 0.365 nm.
(32)
Importantly, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping images further demonstrated that C, Co, P, and O elements were homogeneously distributed within the entire CNT matrix without forming any aggregates or nanoparticles (
Figure
1
e). Quantitative analysis of EDS revealed that the atomic percentages of C, O, Co, and P are approximately 76.77, 14.65, 5.39, and 3.19 at % (
Figure S2
). In addition, inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopic (ICP-MS) testing discloses that the atomic content of cobalt in Co–P SAC MWCNT is about 5.06 at % (
Table S1
), which well agrees with the EDS analysis (
Figure S2
). Generally, it is difficult to clearly understand the reaction mechanism between the pulse laser and the precursors because of ultrafast pressure and temperature changes during PLC process. On the basis of the previous research, we carefully deduced the possible mechanism of fast fabrication of SACs via PLC in liquid as follows.
(27,30)
First, when the pulse laser is injected into the mixed solution (i.e., MWCNT, Co, P, ethanol), extremely harsh environments, such as high-pressure and high-temperature, are created owing to multiphoton absorption ionization.
(28,31)
Subsequently, the high energy plasma plume with cavitation bubbles is formed in the mixed solution, which is known as an intrinsic phenomenon of the pulsed laser ablation process, leading to the formation of the Co and P containing precursors. As a result, the atomic Co and P elements can be effectively formed during the PLC process. Simultaneously, the chemical bonds at the outer walls of MWCNT can be partially cut by the irradiated pulse laser. This induces a high number of defective sites with the unsaturated electronic configurations on the MWCNT where the dissociated Co and P atoms in the solution can be favorably confined into the carbon framework resulting in Co–P SAC MWCNT. It is noteworthy that the Co–P MWCNT control sample (see the experimental details in the
Experimental Section
) exhibited a totally different morphology than that of Co–P SAC MWCNT (
Figure S3
). A bulky particle with CNT on the surface was observed in low-resolution TEM images (
Figure
1
f,g). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern indicated a relatively poor crystallinity of Co–P MWCNT (inset of
Figure
1
g). However, a lattice fringe of 0.365 nm was distinctly detected, which is associated with the graphitic carbon shells of CNT (
Figure
1
h). In addition, EDS mapping images revealed that Co and P existed in a large cobalt phosphide particle (approximately a few microns), while C was detected on the tube (
Figure
1
i). The presence of O in the particle indicated the partial oxidation of cobalt phosphide for Co–P MWCNT. These confirmed that Co–P MWCNT comprised crystalline CNTs composited with amorphous-like cobalt phosphide particles.

div.p: Figure 1. (a) Schematic illustration of material design concept for Co–P SAC MWCNT. (b, c) Low-resolution TEM image for Co–P SAC MWCNT and the corresponding Fast Fourier transformation (FFT) patterns (inset). (d) HR-TEM image of Co–P SAC MWCNT, which indicates the lattice plane of CNT (yellow line). (e) Elemental mapping image for C, Co, P, and O in as-prepared Co–P SAC MWCNT. (f, g) Low-resolution TEM image for Co–P MWCNT and the corresponding SAED pattern (inset). (h) HR-TEM image of Co–P MWCNT, which indicates the lattice plane of CNT (yellow line). (i) Elemental mapping image for C, Co, P, and O in as-prepared Co–P MWCNT. (j) XRD patterns of Co–P SAC MWCNT and Co–P MWCNT. (k) HADDF-STEM image of Co–P SAC MWCNT with the elemental mapping image for (l) C, (m) Co, and (n) P in Co–P SAC MWCNT.

div.div:
Co–P SAC MWCNT and Co–P MWCNT exhibited very similar X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (
Figure
1
j). Only one broad diffraction peak near 2θ = 26.5°, attributable to the (002) plane of the graphitic carbon, was observed for both samples, where no diffraction peaks related to the metallic Co or CoP phase were observed. Importantly, the high angle annular dark field (HAADF) scanning TEM (STEM) image in
Figure
1
k revealed that the atomically isolated Co and P atoms (red arrows) can be uniformly observed on the walls of MWCNT. In addition, elemental mapping images confirm that C, Co, and P elements are homogeneously distributed over the entire MWCNT matrix (
Figure
1
i–n). Thus, the atomic scale incorporation of Co and P with a doping level of approximately 8.58 at% into the CNT matrix was successfully completed using a facile PLC process. We calculated the accurate density of Co single atoms by the following equation:
(33)
(1)
where [Co loading] is 20 wt % determined from the ICP-MS result, N
A
is the Avogadro’s number, and the [surface area] is 330.5654 m
2
g
–1
determined from the BET surface area measurement. The calculated density of Co atoms is approximately 6.18 atom nm
–2
, which is close to the Co single atom density estimated by counting on high-resolution HADDF-STEM images (
Figure
1
k). Compared with the wet-chemical methods (1–2 atoms nm
–2
), the PLC process shows a much higher density of Co atoms, highlighting advantages of the PLC process to load a high number of SACs on the carbon matrix.
(33)
This can be attributed to high energy input on the highly focused area with extremely short time period by the pulsed laser. Thus, the PLC process can be one of the highly promising routes to the synthesis of SACs for OER catalysts

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out to study surface chemical and electronic structures. Three different samples, namely CoP MWCNT, Co–P MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT, were tested to examine the effects of physicochemical interactions induced by laser irradiation on surface chemical states (
Figure
2
). It is noteworthy that CoP and MWCNT were separately prepared using the PLC process for the Co–P SAC MWCNT sample. In contrast, only PLC was used for CoP, and MWCNT was used as-received for preparing the CoP MWCNT sample. Subsequently, mechanical mixing was performed using a mortar and pestle to prepare both CoP MWCNT and Co–P MWCNT. The Co 2p XPS spectra are best fitted with two spin orbit doublets, which are attributed to Co 2p
3/2
and Co 2p
1/2
, respectively. In addition, the peak spacing is about 15.8 eV between the two peaks (Co 2p
3/2
, Co 2p
2/1
), which indicates the presence of both Co
2+
and Co
3+
.
(34,35)
The previous literature reported that the single-atomic Co shows a distinct up-shifting tendency in Co 2p spectra because of its strongly coordinate nature between the Co and nonmetal atom.
(34)
In our case, the EXAFS result indicates that Co has the nearest atomic distance of 2.2535 Å corresponding to the average Co–P distance, which is much higher than the typical Co–O distance of 2.12 Å as shown in
Figure
5
b (discussed in the
X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy
section).
(36)
In addition, the Co peak in XPS spectra showed a distinct up-shift, signifying that the P atoms are atomically coordinated with the Co atoms. Moreover, the pulsed laser process could generate the oxygen functional groups by the decomposition of the solvent (i.e., ethanol in this work), resulting in an increase in the concentration of oxygen groups on the surface of products.
(28)
We also recently reported the formation mechanism of oxygen groups on the surface of carbon nanostructures during pulse laser ablation in liquid process, using experimental and theoretical studies.
(27)
Thus, the enhanced oxygen related peaks (∼785 eV) in the Co 2p XPS spectra for Co–P SAC MWCNT are perhaps related with the functional groups (e.g., OH or O) adsorbed on the surface of MWCNT (
Figure
2
a).
(37,38)
Significant change was observed for C 1s spectra among the samples (
Figure
2
b). Meanwhile, on the MWCNT surface, the PLC process modulated the electronic configuration of the MWCNT matrix. The C 1s spectra of both Co-PMWCNT and Co–P SAC MWCNT clearly showed surface functional groups, such as C–O or C═O, whereas that of CoP MWCNT only showed a deconvoluted C–O peak centered at 286.2 eV with a very small intensity (
Figure
2
b). Oxygenous functional groups on the surfaces of samples could be derived from physicochemical interactions between the MWCNT support and hydroxyl molecules dissociated from the solvent when the pulsed laser was irradiated. Notably, the relative fractions of the deconvoluted C–O and C═O peaks were significantly lower for Co–P SAC MWCNT than those for Co–P MWCNT. This means that the MWCNT matrix in Co–P SAC MWCNT still reserves a high quantity of single atomic sites that are available for incorporating Co or P atoms. More importantly, with respect to the Co–P SAC MWCNT, P 2p XPS spectra exhibit two sets of doublets at 133.4, 134.4, 135.83, and 136.73 eV, which correspond to P 2p
3
and 2p
1
for P
0
in metallic Co–P and P
5+
in P–O bonds, respectively (
Figure
2
c). However, CoP MWCNT and Co–P MWCNT show only metallic P
0
peaks for P 2p XPS spectra. This also indicates the successful incorporation of P atoms on the surface of the MWCNT matrix for Co–P SAC MWCNT, highlighting the advantages of PLC for confining foreign atoms on the carbon matrix with the modulated electronic structure.

div.p: Figure 2. XPS spectra of CoP MWCNTs, Co–P MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT: (a) Co 2p, (b) C 1s, (c) P 2p.

div.div:
The atomic structure of Co–P SAC MWCNT may substantially affect its catalytic performance. The electrocatalytic activity of Co–P SAC MWCNT was tested in 1 M KOH aqueous solution using a three-electrode system with a rotating disk electrode (RDE). A loading amount of samples was about 0.28 mg cm
–2
. For comparison, MWCNT, CoP, Co–P MWCNT, and the benchmark catalyst RuO
2
were also tested in the 1 M KOH solution. CoP was prepared via PLC using a cobalt precursor (Co(No
3
)
2
·6H
2
O) in phosphoric acid and water solvent. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and TEM EDX mapping results showed that CoP has a bulky irregular particle shape with homogeneous distributions of Co and P over the surface (
Figures S4 and S5
). Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was performed on the samples (
Figure
3
a), and the results showed that Co–P SAC MWCNT exhibited outstanding catalytic activity for water oxidation. The overpotential (η) for delivering a current density of 10 mA cm
–2
(η
10
) was estimated as 290 mV for Co–P SAC MWCNT. Notably, the benchmark RuO
2
generated the same current density at 390 mV. The control samples of CoP and Co–P MWCNT exhibited η
10
values of 346 and 330 mV, respectively, revealing that the Co–P SAC MWCNT had much higher electrocatalytic OER activity. Furthermore, the significantly lower η
10
of Co–P SAC MWCNT than that of Co–P MWCNT can be attributed to the physicochemical interactions between catalytic reactive centers (i.e., Co–P) and conductive supports (i.e., MWCNT) with intriguing atomic- and nanostructures. These results indicate the advantages of PLC for designing high-performance OER electrocatalysts. In addition, an overpotential of only 360 mV is needed for Co–P SAC MWCNT to obtain 100 mA cm
–2
, which shows how Co–P SAC MWCNT is better for gaining high current density at low overpotential.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a, b) OER polarization curves (scan rate 5 mVs
–1
) and corresponding Tafel plots for MWCNT (yellow), CoP (blue), Co–P MWCNT (gray), Co–P SAC MWCNT (red), and commercial RuO
2
(purple) catalysts loaded on a RDE (2000 rpm) in an O
2
-saturated 1.0 M KOH solution. (c) Nyquist plots of MWCNT (yellow), CoP (blue), Co–P MWCNT (gray), Co–P SAC MWCNT (red), and commercial RuO
2
(purple). The inset shows the Randles equivalent circuit model. (d) Current difference between anodic and cathodic sweeps as a function of scan rate. The slope of the fitted line was used to calculate C
dl
. (e) TOF at an overpotential of 290 mV. (f) Chronoamperometry curve of Co–P SAC MWCNT under an applied voltage of 1.52 V.

div.div:
Different amounts of cobalt precursor and phosphoric acidic solution were used for PLC to determine an optimal synthetic condition for yielding the best water oxidation properties of Co–P SAC MWCNT. LSV data measured in the 1.0 M KOH solution (
Figure S6a
) revealed that the best synthetic condition is under 1.5 g of Co(No
3
)
2
·6H
2
O with 20 mL of phosphoric acidic solution. Furthermore, we performed postheat treatment at different temperatures (50–400 °C) with a constant H
2
flow (500 sccm) to thermally activate Co–P SAC MWCNT. The as-prepared Co–P SAC MWCNT exhibited the best electrocatalytic performance for OER, indicating that thermal activation may degrade the catalytic properties of Co–P SAC MWCNT (
Figure S6b
). During thermal activation, the abundant single atomic reactive sites for catalysis may aggregate and nanoclusters may develop, resulting in a significant loss in the number of active sites and, thereby, reduced catalytic activity. Given that the total time for our PLC process is less than 60 min and no subsequent process such as thermal or chemical treatments is needed, the material design strategy for developing SACs using PLC is attractive from not only a scientific aspect but also an industrial aspect.

Tafel plots of the samples were derived from the LSV polarization curves based on the Tafel equation (η =
b
× log
j
+
a
), where η is the overpotential,
j
is the current density, and
b
is the Tafel slope (
Figure
3
b). The smallest Tafel slope of 64 mV dec
–1
was observed for Co–P SAC MWCNT, followed by CoP (83 mV dec
–1
), RuO
2
(117 mV dec
–1
), MWCNT (149 mV dec
–1
), and Co–P MWCNT (163 mV dec
–1
). This means that the reaction kinetic may be faster in Co–P SAC MWCNT for the rate-limiting step (RDS) associated with electrochemical charge transfer.
(39)
The electrocatalytic properties of Co–P SAC MWCNT were compared with those of recently reported state-of-the-art water oxidation catalysts (
Table S2
). The comparison revealed the superior catalytic performance of Co–P SAC MWCNT, surpassing or rivaling those of most transition or noble metal-based catalysts. More importantly, compared with those Co-based SAC, the PLC process has a significantly shorter processing time with higher concentration of SACs. Hence, the PLC process can be one of the promising practical techniques to realize the use of SACs for actual alkaline electrolyzer (
Table S3
).

Charge transfer resistance (
R
ct
) between the surfaces of catalysts and the electrolytes can be estimated from the semicircle diameter in the high-frequency region of a Nyquist plot (
Z
′ vs −
Z
″), where smaller diameters generally correspond to lower R
ct
values.
(40)
The Nyquist plots of samples were fitted using Randles equivalent circuit models to calculate the R
ct
value as shown in
Figures
3
c and
S7
. RuO
2
and CoP showed relatively large R
ct
values of 45.2 and 55.5 Ω, respectively; in contrast, low R
ct
values were obtained for MWCNT (21.1 Ω), Co–P MWCNT (7.3 Ω), and Co–P SAC MWCNT (17.6 Ω). In other words, the highly conductive MWCNT plays a crucial role in enhancing charge transfer at the interface between catalysts and reactants. Interestingly, the R
ct
value of Co–P MWCNT was lower than that of Co–P SAC MWCNT, which can be attributed to the synergetic effect of both metallic CoP and MWCNT phases for facilitating charge transport. However, LSV polarization curves clearly revealed much lower catalytic activity of the former than the latter. To reconfirm this, a detailed quantitative analysis for electrocatalytic activity of the samples is required.

First, we calculated double-layer capacitance (C
dl
) using a cyclic voltammetry (CV) method. CV curves were measured in the non-Faradaic region where the current is generated from electrical double layer charging (
Figure S8
).
(41)
The C
dl
values of CoP, Co–P MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT were estimated as 52.72, 82.42, and 71.38 mF cm
–2
, respectively (
Figure
3
d). Notably, the C
dl
of MWCNT is negligible because of its poor capacitance. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) can be obtained from C
dl
using the linear relationship between them. Generally, the specific capacitance of a 1 cm
2
flat surface area (C
s
) is approximately equal to 40 μF cm
–2
.
(39)
Therefore, the ECSA can be calculated as
(2)
Note that C
s
in the KOH solution is in the range of 22–130 μF cm
–2
, and ECSA calculated from C
dl
is accurate within one order of magnitude.
(39)
The ECSAs of CoP, Co–P MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT were found to be 1318, 2060, and 1784 cm
2
, respectively, which are extremely high values compared to those of other reported catalysts.
(40,42)
This can be attributed to the high surface areas as well as abundant reactive centers on the nanostructured catalyst surfaces induced by PLC. For quantitative comparison, LSV polarization curves of the catalysts were normalized with ECSA (
Figure S9
), and the results consistently revealed the superior performance of Co–P SAC MWCNT over the CoP and Co–P MWCNT counterparts. These results prove the intrinsically superior catalytic activity of Co–P SAC MWCNT.

Next, the turnover frequency (TOF) of the catalysts for water oxidation was calculated as
(3)
where
j
is the current density (A cm
–2
) at a specific overpotential,
A
is the electrode area (cm
2
),
F
is the Faraday constant (96 485 C mol
–1
), and
N
s
is the concentration of active sites (mol cm
–2
).
(43)
Here,
N
s
can be obtained from the linear relationship between the peak current of the oxidation wave and scan rate.
(44)
N
s
values for CoP, Co–P MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT were calculated to be 1.05 × 10
–7
, 1.29 × 10
–7
, and 2.06 × 10
–7
mol cm
–2
from the linear plot (
Figure S10
). If heterogeneous catalysis is considered to occur only on the surface, while the inner bulk remains electroactive, the estimated
N
s
value is an upper limit for the active sites. TOF was found to be 0.0088 s
–1
for Co–P SAC MWCNT at an overpotential of 290 mV, which is approximately two-times higher than those of CoP (0.004 s
–1
) and Co–P MWCNT (0.0039 s
–1
) (
Figure
3
e). This further highlights the excellent intrinsic catalytic activity of Co–P SAC MWCNT for water oxidation.

In addition to good activity, electrochemical stability of the catalysts is also significant from a practical perspective. Thus, the electrocatalytic durability of Co–P SAC MWCNT for OER was tested through chronoamperometric (CA) measurements. We performed the CV cycling, 50 cycles in the voltage range of 1.23–1.5 V
RHE
in alkaline media to electrochemically activate the surface of Co–P SAC MWCNT before stability test. Notably, after 10 h of water oxidation at 1.52 V in 1.0 M KOH, Co–P SAC MWCNT retained approximately 100% of the initial current density with negligible degradation (
Figure
3
f). The current density increased at the beginning of the CA test, which could be due to the surface reconfiguration of the single atomic species or hydroxyl functional groups on the MWCNT. Hydroxyl functional groups may form on the surface of MWCNT during PLC.
(27)
Moreover, the functional groups definitely undergo OER when voltage is applied, potentially increasing current density at the initial stage of CA. Structural and chemical changes after OER were investigated for Co–P SAC MWCNT using TEM and XPS.
Figure S11
shows low-resolution TEM image of post-OER (after 10 h CA test) Co–P SAC MWCNT sample with EDS mapping results for C, O, P, and Co. The pristine tubular structure was well retained for the post-OER Co–P SAC MWCNT. Importantly, EDS mapping images reveal that Co and P were homogeneously presented in single-atomic structure on the surface of MWCNT matrix. This implies the absence of nanoclusters or aggregates during long-term OER due to a rigidly anchored Co and P single atoms on the matrix via PLC technique. In addition, high-resolution XPS scans confirmed clear evidence for the existence of Co atoms in the post-OER Co–P SAC MWCNT (
Figure S12a
). Notably, the electronic state of Co was not significantly changed after long-term OER compared to the original state. For C 1s XPS spectra, in addition to C–C and C–O bonds, C 1s peaks related with C–F or K 2p peaks were also detected, which can be associated with the organic binder (i.e., Nafion) or electrolyte (1 M KOH), respectively, used for the electrochemical test (
Figure S12b
). Overall, these results verify that Co–P SAC MWCNT is a very promising catalyst for alkaline OER with high activity as well as stability that outperforms or rivals recently developed state-of-the-art OER catalysts including the benchmark RuO
2
catalyst. Moreover, the synthetic method via PLC further strengthens its potential use with high cost-effectiveness for practical applications.

To investigate individual roles of Co and P, we prepared control samples of Co-SAC MWCNT and P-SAC MWCNT using PLC (see the experimental details in the
Experimental Section
). SEM images revealed homogeneous tubular structures of Co-SAC MWCNT and P-SAC MWCNT with no detectable aggregated particles (
Figure S13
). XRD patterns of the samples also indicated that diffraction peaks were observed only for the CNT phase (JCPDS no. 01–0646) (
Figure S14
). LSV polarization curves for OER were then measured using an identical measurement setup for Co–P SAC MWCNT.
Figure
4
a reveals that the η
10
values of Co-SAC MWCNT and P-SAC MWCNT were approximately 310 and 350 mV, respectively, which are much higher than that of Co–P SAC MWCNT (290 mV). Furthermore, the corresponding Tafel slopes for Co-SAC MWCNT and P-SAC MWCNT were calculated as 46 and 73 mV dec
–1
, respectively (
Figure
4
b). Co-SAC MWCNT exhibited a slightly lower Tafel slope than that of Co–P SAC MWCNT, indicating that Co may play a crucial role in facilitating reaction kinetics. The estimated values of C
dl
of Co-SAC MWCNT and P-SAC MWCNT were 1.54 and 0.26 mF cm
–2
, respectively (
Figure S15
), which are much lower than that of Co–P SAC MWCNT (71.38 mF cm
–2
). Notably, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) illustrated that Co–P SAC MWCNT had significantly lower R
ct
(17.6 Ω) than those of Co-SAC MWCNT PLA (28.1 Ω) and P-SAC MWCNT (36.7 Ω) (
Figure
4
c). The Nyquist plots of samples were fitted using Randles equivalent circuit models to calculate the R
ct
value as shown in
Figures
4
c and
S16
. Thus, P may assist charge transfer between the active sites in Co–P SAC MWCNT (i.e., possibly Co atoms) and external chemical reactants (i.e., hydroxyl ions or water molecules). These possibilities are further discussed in detail in the following section. A long-term CA measurement was also performed on Co-SAC MWCNT and P-SAC MWCNT (
Figure S17
). After 10 h of water oxidation at 1.54 V in 1.0 M KOH, Co-SAC MWCNT and P-SAC MWCNT displayed approximately 70% of the initial current density output, indicating higher degradation rates than those of Co–P SAC MWCNT. Therefore, the synergetic effect between Co and P is important to secure robust electrocatalytic stability of Co–P SAC MWCNT for alkaline water oxidation.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a, b) OER polarization curves (scan rate 5 mVs
–1
) and corresponding Tafel plots for Co-SAC MWCNT (blue), P-SAC MWCNT (gray), and Co–P SAC MWCNT (red) catalysts loaded on a RDE (2000 rpm) in an O
2
-saturated 1.0 M KOH solution. (c) Nyquist plots of Co-SAC MWCNT (blue), P-SAC MWCNT (gray), and Co–P SAC MWCNT (red). The inset shows the Randles equivalent circuit model.

div.div:
The local structure of Co–P SAC MWCNT was characterized using X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). Synchrotron-based Co K-edge XAS was conducted to gain insights into oxidation state and coordination geometry. For comparison purposes, CoP was also analyzed by XAS.
Figure
5
a shows the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) of CoP and Co–P SAC MWCNT along with Co metallic foil. The XANES spectrum of CoP is noticed at higher energy compared to the Co foil, indicating the formation of CoP phase. Co K-edge XANES spectrum of Co–P SAC MWCNT is noticed with the similar main edge features as compared to CoP except the main peak is shifted by 0.5 eV to higher energy. This shift in main peak energy could be attributed to the presence of MWCNT. To further probe the local environment in 3-dimensional visualization around the Co atom in CoP and Co–P SAC MWCNT, the Continuous Cauchy wavelet transform (CCWT) analysis was conducted at Co K-edge as shown in
Figure
5
c–e. The color intensity on left
y
-axis links to the CCWT modulus, corresponding to the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) amplitude.
Figure
5
c shows the CCWT visualization for CoP plotted in k-space (
x
-axis), R-space (left
y
-axis, uncorrected phase shift), and color intensity (right
y
-axis). Two major peaks at 1.61 and 2.744 Å can be observed from the CCWT of CoP. The first intense peak at 1.61 Å corresponds to the Co–P interaction, while the second peak is attributed to the Co–Co interaction; the third peak at a higher interatomic distance of 3.84 Å was also observed with the week intensity, which is attributed to the combined Co–P and Co–Co interactions as shown in in the crystal structure of CoP (
Figure S18
).
Figure
5
d shows the CCWT modulus of Co–P SAC MWCNT, which indicates three peaks at 1.585, 2.775, and 3.746 Å, respectively. It was noticed that the peak intensity and the interatomic distance of the first peak are reduced in CCWT of Co–P SAC MWCNT compared to CoP. This may be due to the additional Co–C interaction in the Co–P SAC MWCNT as Co is incorporated on the MWCNT matrix as a single atomic configuration.
Figure
5
e shows the CCWT of Co metallic foil, which indicates two major peaks at 2.149 and 4.2001 Å. Notably, these peaks from Co metallic foil were not observed for the CCWT of Co–P SAC MWCNT probably due to the presence of P atoms next to Co atoms. In addition, to further investigate the local coordination environment of Co–P SAC MWCNT, we have performed the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analysis. The simulated Fourier transformed extended X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) of Co–P SAC MWCNT shows first peak from Co–P interactions (
Figure
5
b). The average Co–P distance was determined to be 2.2535 Å, which is higher than the typical Co–O distance of 2.12 Å, indicating the nearest Co–P coordination.
(36)
The second and third peaks could be assigned to Co–Co and Co–C interaction as can be seen in
Table S4
.
(45)
As can be seen in the DFT calculation (
Figure S19
), in a thermodynamic point of view, the local atomic structure of Co–P, where P located at the nearest site with Co, is the most favorable configuration when Co and P are simultaneously incorporated in the carbon matrix. This is similar to the Co–N atomic configuration generally found in Co SAC in nitrogen-doped carbon-based materials.
(34)
Additionally, the XRD pattern (
Figure
1
g) and the EDS mapping images (
Figure
1
e) strongly support the absence of cobalt phosphide phases in the Co–P SAC MWCNT. Thus, it is reasonable to note that the observed Co–P coordination in the FT-EXAFS of Co–P SAC MWCNT is associated with the single-atomic Co and P atoms with the nearest coordination. Moreover, we reason the existence of the Co–Co coordination in the FT-EXAFS of Co–P SAC MWCNT to the higher concentration of Co (about two-times) than P atoms as revealed by ICP-MS and EDS mapping results. In other words, it is highly plausible that the second Co atom rather than P atom can be incorporated on the neighboring sites to the initially incorporated Co atoms in the matrix due to the higher number of Co atoms relative to P atom.

div.p: Figure 5. (a) Co K-edge XANES spectra of CoP, Co–P SAC MWCNT, and Co metallic foil. (b) FT-EXAFS of Co–P SAC MWCNT at Co K-edge. (c–e) Continuous Cauchy wavelet transform (CCWT) visualization of Co K-edge EXAFS of CoP, Co–P SAC MWCNT, and Co metallic foil.

div.div:
We performed DFT calculations to acquire a fundamental understanding of the OER mechanism in Co–P SAC MWCNT. First, systematic DFT calculations were performed, and the adsorption free energies of intermediates (i.e., OH*, O*, and OOH*) were compared using different models, such as MWCNT, Co-SAC MWCNT, P-SAC MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT, during OER (
Figures S19 and S20
). Two different atomic configurations, Co–P (1NN) and Co–P (2NN), were considered for modeling Co–P SAC MWCNT. Binding energies of Co–P were 1.28 and 0.79 eV for Co–P (1NN) and Co–P (2NN), respectively, indicating an attractive bonding force between two atoms. Additionally, defect formation energies of the simulated models for inducing Co or P SACs in the carbon matrix are summarized in
Table S5
.

The simulated atomic structures of OH*, O*, and OOH* adsorbed on the surfaces of MWCNT, Co-SAC MWCNT, P-SAC MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT are presented in
Figures S21 and S22
. For Co–P SAC MWCNT, both Co and P sites were considered as possible adsorption sites for all OER steps. Stable adsorption without dissociation of the intermediates was observed in all OER steps. The OER energy diagrams for the thermodynamically favorable adsorption sites were simulated for reaction steps (I to IV) corresponding to OH*, O*, and OOH* adsorptions on MWCNT, Co-SAC MWCNT, P-SAC MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT, which can be described as follows:
(4)
(5)
(6)
(7)
where ∗ represents an active site on the surface of catalyst. The obtained Gibbs free energies (Δ
G
) of
reactions 4
–
7
are presented in
Figure
6
a. The pristine MWCNT showed a significant high uphill Δ
G
change for reaction steps I and III, indicating unfavorable OER reaction kinetics. In contrast, intermediates were bound more strongly with a huge negative change in Δ
G
when Co, P, or Co–P were incorporated in MWCNT. More significant negative Δ
G
change was found for Co- and Co–P SAC MWCNT than for P-SAC MWCNT. In addition, the subsequent Δ
G
profiles revealed that reaction step II occurred spontaneously in P-SAC MWCNT and Co–P SAC MWCNT, whereas Co-SAC MWCNT showed a slight positive change in Δ
G
. Accordingly, Co and P can be ascertained to have respective roles for boosting alkaline OER in Co–P SAC MWCNT. In other words, Co plays a crucial role in facilitating OH* adsorption on the surface (step I), while P further promotes desorption of hydrogen from OH* (step II). Consequently, Co–P SAC MWCNT achieves strong OH* adsorption and H* desorption simultaneously, which is exceptionally advantageous for enhancing alkaline OER kinetics.

Notably, the reaction step with the largest energy barrier is RDS; step III (i.e., OOH* formation) acts as the RDS of OER in all simulated models, namely MWCNT, Co-SAC MWCNT, P-SAC MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT, examined in this study. The pristine MWCNT and P-SAC MWCNT showed a much larger energy barrier for RDS as 4.83 and 4.59 eV, respectively, compared with those of Co-SAC MWCNT (1.64 eV) and Co–P SAC MWCNT (2.04 eV), implying the key role of Co in securing favorable thermodynamics for OER (
Figure
6
a). Furthermore, given that the atomic structure of Co–P (2NN) exhibited a much favorable Δ
G
profile for OER than that of Co–P (1NN) (
Figure S23
), Co SAC incorporated into MWCNT with a Co–P (2NN) configuration is a promising active site of Co–P SAC MWCNT for alkaline water oxidation.

The formation of covalent bonds between metal atoms and a two-dimensional semiconductor (2D-SC), such as MWCNTs, can metallize the surface of 2D-SC, eliminating the van der Waals gap between the metal and 2D-SC.
(46,47)
Hence, the energy band structure and the charge distribution near Co- or P SACs incorporated in MWCNT must be further investigated, which can provide comprehensive understanding of the charge transfer characteristics of Co–P SAC MWCNT for water oxidation.
Figure
6
b shows the total density-of-states (
t
-DOS) plots for MWCNT, Co-SAC MWCNT, P-SAC MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT. For comparison, partial DOS (
p
-DOS) plots are also summarized in
Figures S24 and S25
. The DOS plots of MWCNT and Co-SAC MWCNT show that DOS near the Fermi level (E
F
) was unambiguously reduced for Co-SAC MWCNT although energy states increased within the bandgap of MWCNT after the incorporation of Co (
Figure
6
b). In sharp contrast, Co–P SAC and P-SAC MWCNTs showed a significant enhancement in DOS at E
F
compared to the pristine MWCNT (
Figure
6
b). In particular, Co–P SAC MWCNT exhibited the highest DOS near E
F
among the simulated models, suggesting the synergetic effects of Co and P on improving the electrical properties of Co–P SAC MWCNT. As a result, a fast charge transfer can be expected for Co–P SAC MWCNT between the catalyst surface and adsorbents during alkaline OER.

To reach a comprehensive understanding of the key role of P in OER activity, we simulated the detailed local electronic configuration for all adsorption steps in case of MWCNT, Co-SAC MWCNT, P-SAC MWCNT, and Co–P SAC MWCNT (
Figures
6
c–f,
S26, S27
).
Figure
6
c–f present the spatial charge distributions of the simulated models with OOH* adsorbed onto the surface, where the electron-rich and electron-deficient regions are indicated in yellow and cyan, respectively. The figure shows the formation of obvious electron accumulation and depletion areas around the cobalt in MWCNT (
Figure
6
d). More importantly, in
Figure
6
f, an apparent new charge polarization is induced by incorporating the P atom adjacent to the Co atom. The most significant change is the formation of the charge depletion region near at the P–C bond, which was not detected in the case of P-SAC MWCNT (
Figure
6
e). This transformation may significantly enhance charge transfer between the intermediates and the catalyst surface, thereby promising more facile kinetics in alkaline OER. Notably, charge transformation was also observed between the adsorbents and P–C bond for OH* and O* adsorptions, as shown in
Figures S26d and 27d
, respectively. Thus, the coexistence of Co and P in the 2NN SAC configuration in the carbon matrix can be ascertained to be particularly essential for achieving advantageous thermodynamics as well as kinetics for alkaline water oxidation in Co–P SAC MWCNT.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, Co and P single atoms were successfully confined on the conductive CNT matrix via a developed PLC process in liquid. Co–P SAC MWCNT exhibited a high loading density of SACs and strong interaction with the CNT supports. Energy landscape of Co–P SAC MWCNT for OER could be optimized by Co SACs; meanwhile, P SACs facilitate charge transfer between the catalyst surface and adsorbents leading to favorable catalytic reaction thermodynamics as well as kinetics. Apparently, this positions Co–P SAC MWCNT as one of the most effective and robust OER electrocatalysts reported to date. The Co–P SAC MWCNT demonstrated superior electrocatalytic performance for alkaline water oxidation such as a low overpotential (290 mV for affording 10 mA cm
–2
), a low Tafel slope (64 mV dec
–1
), and a high turnover frequency (0.0088 s
–1
at an overpotential of 290 mV) with an excellent stability. The material design concept for SACs using PLC with a fast quenching effect is promising for synthesizing high-performance electrocatalysts, which can be applicable to a variety of electrochemical energy conversion or storage devices.

div.div:
Pristine MWCNTs were purchased from Hanwha chemical (Republic of Korea). High-purity ethanol (99.9%), cobalt nitrate (Co(NO
3
)
2
·6H
2
O), and phosphoric acid (H
3
PO
4
) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (USA) and used as-received without further purification.

CoP nanoparticles were fabricated by a one-step pulse laser ablation process. In a typical process, 1.5 g of cobalt nitrate and 30 mL of phosphoric acid were dissolved in 0.5 L of high-purity ethanol. High-power sonication was subsequently performed during laser ablation for vigorous dispersion of each precursor (e.g., Co, P). Laser ablation was performed on the mixed suspension for 60 min at room temperature and in the air using a Q-switch ND:YAG laser system. The mixed suspension was ablated by a vertical pulsed laser beam (355 nm, third harmonic) at a repetition rate of 10 Hz. The pulse width was 10 nm, and the ablation energy was 1 J. After the pulse laser ablation, subsequent centrifuging and drying processes provided CoP.

The laser irradiation power intensity is calculated by our previous report, as can be seen:
(27)
(8)
where P
s
is the laser power density (W/cm
2
), E is laser energy (J), t is the pulsed width (s), and s is laser facula area (cm
2
). According to our experimental parameters (1 J), the calculated laser irradiation power intensity is 318 × 10
7
W/cm
2
.

As-prepared 0.1 g of CoP was mechanically mixed with 0.1 g of MWCNTs, where the identical PLA process was applied, in the Porcelain mortar. The mechanical mixing was performed for 10 min using mortar and pestle.
As-prepared 0.1 g of CoP was with 0.1 g of MWCNTs, where no PLA process was applied, in the Porcelain mortar. Mechanical mixing was performed for 10 min using mortar and pestle.

Co-SAC MWCNT was prepared by pulsed laser ablation process. For this, 1.5 g of cobalt nitrate and 0.1 g of MWCNT were dissolved in 0.5 L of high purity ethanol. Then the same pulsed laser experimental condition as the synthesis of CoP experimental condition was performed.

P-SAC MWCNT was prepared by pulsed laser ablation process. Thirty milliliters of phosphoric acid and 0.1 g of MWCNT were dissolved in 0.5 L of high purity ethanol. Then the same pulsed laser experimental condition as the synthesis of CoP experimental condition was performed.

Co–P SAC MWCNT was prepared by pulsed laser ablation process. For this, 1.5 g of cobalt nitrate, 30 mL of phosphoric acid, and 0.1 g of MWCNT were dissolved in 0.5 L of high purity ethanol. Then the same pulsed laser experimental condition as the synthesis of CoP experimental condition was performed.

Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S4800) was employed to study microstructural images of the samples. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and the high angle annular dark field (HAADF) scanning TEM were performed using JEM ARM 200F (JEOL). Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping images were acquired using a Talos F200X (Thermo Fisher Scientific) microscope equipped with an EDX analyzer at 200 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a D/MAX-2500/PC (Rigaku) diffractometer with Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm) at 40 kV and 100 mA. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were measured using a VG ESCALAB 200i (Thermo Fisher Scientific), where survey and high-resolution scans were conducted with pass energies of 100 and 20 eV, respectively.

Electrochemical properties were tested in 1 M KOH using a three-electrode electrochemical cell with a rotating disk electrode (RDE) controlled by an electrochemistry workstation (Autolab PGSTAT, Metrohm). For the preparation of the working electrode, a 4 mg of sample was dispersed in a 1 mL of water and ethanol (volume ratio 3:1) solution with a 30 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt %, Sigma-Aldrich). A catalyst ink was formed using ultra sonication. Then the 5 μL of catalyst ink was drop-cast on the surface of a glassy carbon (GC) RDE electrode with a diameter of 3 mm. This yields an approximate catalyst loading of 0.285 mg cm
–2
. The working electrode was then dried overnight in air. The electrolyte was purged with O
2
for about 10 min before measurements. The RDE electrode was kept rotating at 1600 rpm during the measurements to remove bubbles. Ag|AgCl (3.5 M KCl) and Pt foil were used as the reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was performed at a scan rate of 5 mV s
–1
. The potentials were calibrated against reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), and all polarization curves were
iR
-compensated. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was measured in the frequency range of 0.1–100 kHz. A sinusoidal voltage with amplitude of 5 mV was applied during the EIS measurements.

X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) of CoP and Co–P SAC MWCNT samples was measured at the KIST-1D beamline of the Pohang Light Source (PLS-II) with ring energy and current of 3 GeV and 280 mA. A double crystal Si(111) monochromator was used to detune the incident beam by 40% to suppress the higher harmonics. Co K-edge was calibrated using Co metallic foil prior measurements and XAS spectra of CoP, and Co–P SAC MWCNT samples were recorded in transmission mode. The background subtraction, normalization, edge energy, and
k
-space conversion of XAS data were processed in ATHENA software.
(48)
The processed XAS data were transformed to k-space over a range of 3.0–10.0 Å
–1
. The Continuous Cauchy wavelet transform (CCWT) analysis was performed with k
3
-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum.
(49)

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) parametrization and Quantum ESPRESSO program.
(50)
We used 2 × 3 × 2 k-point grids and a 80 Ry energy cutoff of the wave function. We considered the van der Waals interactions using DFT-D3(BJ) method. The convergence criterions of the structural relaxation and electronic self-consistency for energy and forces set were chosen as 10
7
Ry and 0.00038 Ry/bohr, respectively.

Subbaraman, Ram; Tripkovic, Dusan; Chang, Kee-Chul; Strmcnik, Dusan; Paulikas, Arvydas P.; Hirunsit, Pussana; Chan, Maria; Greeley, Jeff; Stamenkovic, Vojislav; Markovic, Nenad M.

Design and synthesis of materials for efficient electrochem. transformation of H2O to H2 and of hydroxyl ions to O in alk. environments is of paramount importance in reducing energy losses in H2O-alkali electrolyzers. Here, using 3d-M hydr(oxy)oxides, with distinct stoichiometries and morphologies in the H evolution reaction (HER) and the O evolution reaction (OER) regions, the authors establish the overall catalytic activities for these reaction as a function of a more fundamental property, a descriptor, OH-M2+δ bond strength (0 ≤ δ ≤ 1.5). This relation exhibits trends in reactivity (Mn < Fe < Co < Ni), which is governed by the strength of the OH-M2+δ energetic (Ni < Co < Fe < Mn). These trends are independent of the source of the OH, either the supporting electrolyte (for the OER) or the H2O dissocn. product (for the HER). The successful identification of these electrocatalytic trends provides the foundation for rational design of active sites' for practical alk. HER and OER electrocatalysts.

In our efforts to obtain electrocatalysts with improved activity for water splitting, meticulous design and synthesis of the active sites of the electrocatalysts and deciphering how exactly they catalyze the reaction are vitally necessary. Herein, we report a one-step facile synthesis of a novel precious-metal-free hydrogen-evolution nanoelectrocatalyst, dubbed
[email protected]
that is composed of ultrasmall molybdenum carbide (Mo2C) nanoparticles embedded within nitrogen-rich carbon (NC) nanolayers. The
[email protected]
hybrid nanoelectrocatalyst shows remarkable catalytic activity, has great durability, and gives about 100 % Faradaic yield toward the hydrogen-evolution reaction (HER) over a wide pH range (pH 0-14). Theor. calcns. show that the Mo2C and N dopants in the material synergistically co-activate adjacent C atoms on the carbon nanolayers, creating superactive nonmetallic catalytic sites for HER that are more active than those in the constituents.

The utilization of solar energy on a large scale requires its storage. In natural photosynthesis, energy from sunlight is used to rearrange the bonds of water to oxygen and hydrogen equiv. The realization of artificial systems that perform "water splitting" requires catalysts that produce oxygen from water without the need for excessive driving potentials. Here we report such a catalyst that forms upon the oxidative polarization of an inert indium tin oxide electrode in phosphate-buffered water contg. cobalt (II) ions. A variety of anal. techniques indicates the presence of phosphate in an approx. 1:2 ratio with cobalt in this material. The pH dependence of the catalytic activity also implicates the hydrogen phosphate ion as the proton acceptor in the oxygen-producing reaction. This catalyst not only forms in situ from earth-abundant materials but also operates in neutral water under ambient conditions.

A review. Hydrogen is often considered the best means by which to store energy coming from renewable and intermittent power sources. With the growing capacity of localized renewable energy sources surpassing the gigawatt range, a storage system of equal magnitude is required. PEM electrolysis provides a sustainable soln. for the prodn. of hydrogen, and is well suited to couple with energy sources such as wind and solar. However, due to low demand in electrolytic hydrogen in the last century, little research has been done on PEM electrolysis with many challenges still unexplored. The ever increasing desire for green energy has rekindled the interest on PEM electrolysis, thus the compilation and recovery of past research and developments is important and necessary. In this review, PEM water electrolysis is comprehensively highlighted and discussed. The challenges new and old related to electrocatalysts, solid electrolyte, current collectors, separator plates and modeling efforts will also be addressed. The main message is to clearly set the state-of-the-art for the PEM electrolysis technol., be insightful of the research that is already done and the challenges that still exist. This information will provide several future research directions and a road map in order to aid scientists in establishing PEM electrolysis as a com. viable hydrogen prodn. soln.

A review. The development of low-cost, high-efficiency, and robust electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is urgently needed to address the energy crisis. In recent years, non-noble-metal-based OER electrocatalysts have attracted tremendous research attention. Beginning with the introduction of some evaluation criteria for the OER, the current OER electrocatalysts are reviewed, with the classification of metals/alloys, oxides, hydroxides, chalcogenides, phosphides, phosphates/borates, and other compds., along with their advantages and shortcomings. The current knowledge of the reaction mechanisms and practical applications of the OER is also summarized for developing more efficient OER electrocatalysts. Finally, the current states, challenges, and some perspectives for non-noble-metal-based OER electrocatalysts are discussed.

Non-noble metal-nitride based electrocatalysts for high-performance alkaline seawater electrolysis
Yu Luo; Yu Ying; Yu Luo; Zhu Qing; Song Shaowei; McElhenny Brian; Wang Dezhi; Chen Shuo; Ren Zhifeng; Zhu Qing; Song Shaowei; Wu Chunzheng; Qin Zhaojun; Bao Jiming

Seawater is one of the most abundant natural resources on our planet. Electrolysis of seawater is not only a promising approach to produce clean hydrogen energy, but also of great significance to seawater desalination. The implementation of seawater electrolysis requires robust and efficient electrocatalysts that can sustain seawater splitting without chloride corrosion, especially for the anode. Here we report a three-dimensional core-shell metal-nitride catalyst consisting of NiFeN nanoparticles uniformly decorated on NiMoN nanorods supported on Ni foam, which serves as an eminently active and durable oxygen evolution reaction catalyst for alkaline seawater electrolysis. Combined with an efficient hydrogen evolution reaction catalyst of NiMoN nanorods, we have achieved the industrially required current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm(-2) at record low voltages of 1.608 and 1.709 V, respectively, for overall alkaline seawater splitting at 60 °C. This discovery significantly advances the development of seawater electrolysis for large-scale hydrogen production.

The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a known impediment in the development of electrochem. energy conversion and storage devices such as water-splitting electrolyzers and rechargeable metal-air batteries. The intrinsically slow OER kinetics can only be mitigated by effective catalysis. The search for low-cost alternatives to the conventional noble metal-based catalysts is a research priority and has thus far been focused mostly on metal oxides. It is the purpose of this review to outline the opportunities and available options besides the noble metals and metal oxides. These unconventional catalysts include transition metal phosphates, borates, chalcogenides, phosphides, nitrides and borides as well as metal-free carbon-based materials. They are all based on earth-abundant elements with some of them showing higher catalytic performance than the common metal oxides in aq. soln. The review begins with the introduction of the evaluation criteria for OER catalysts. The development and breakthroughs in the unconventional catalysts are then succinctly summarized with discussion of some current scientific issues. We then present our perspectives on these issues and suggest some areas of further work. We hope this review can raise the interest in less common options to broaden the search for practical OER catalysts to beyond the metal oxides.

A review. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a kinetically sluggish anodic reaction and requires a large overpotential to deliver appreciable current. Despite the fact that non-precious metal-based alk. water electrocatalysts are receiving increased attention, noble metal-based electrocatalysts (NMEs) applied in proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers still have advantageous features of larger current and power densities with lower stack cost. Engineering NMEs for OER catalysis with high efficiency, durability and utilization rate is of vital importance in promoting the development of cost-effective renewable energy prodn. and conversion devices. In this tutorial review, we covered the recent progress in the compn. and structure optimization of NMEs for OER including Ir- and Ru-based oxides and alloys, and noble-metals beyond Ir and Ru with a variety of morphologies. To shed light on the fundamental science and mechanisms behind compn./structure-performance relationships and activity-stability relationships, integrated exptl. and theor. studies were pursued for illuminating the metal-support interaction, size effect, heteroatom doping effect, phase transformation, degrdn. processes and single-atom catalysis. Finally, the challenges and outlook are provided for guiding the rational engineering of OER electrocatalysts for applications in renewable energy-related devices.

Platinum-based heterogeneous catalysts are crit. to many important com. chem. processes, but their efficiency is extremely low on a per metal atom basis, because only the surface active-site atoms are used. Catalysts with single-atom dispersions are thus highly desirable to maximize atom efficiency, but making them is challenging. Here we report the synthesis of a single-atom catalyst that consists of only isolated single Pt atoms anchored to the surfaces of iron oxide nanocrystallites. This single-atom catalyst has extremely high atom efficiency and shows excellent stability and high activity for both CO oxidn. and preferential oxidn. of CO in H2. Single-Atom Catalysts: A New Frontier in Heterogeneous Catalysis
Yang, Xiao-Feng; Wang, Aiqin; Qiao, Botao; Li, Jun; Liu, Jingyue; Zhang, Tao

A review; supported metal nanostructures are the most widely used type of heterogeneous catalyst in industrial processes. The size of metal particles is a key factor in detg. the performance of such catalysts. In particular, because low-coordinated metal atoms often function as the catalytically active sites, the specific activity per metal atom usually increases with decreasing size of the metal particles. However, the surface free energy of metals increases significantly with decreasing particle size, promoting aggregation of small clusters. Using an appropriate support material that strongly interacts with the metal species prevents this aggregation, creating stable, finely dispersed metal clusters with a high catalytic activity, an approach industry has used for a long time. Nevertheless, practical supported metal catalysts are inhomogeneous and usually consist of a mixt. of sizes from nanoparticles to subnanometer clusters. Such heterogeneity not only reduces the metal atom efficiency but also frequently leads to undesired side reactions. It also makes it extremely difficult, if not impossible, to uniquely identify and control the active sites of interest. The ultimate small-size limit for metal particles is the single-atom catalyst (SAC), which contains isolated metal atoms singly dispersed on supports. SACs maximize the efficiency of metal atom use, which is particularly important for supported noble metal catalysts. Moreover, with well-defined and uniform single-atom dispersion, SACs offer great potential for achieving high activity and selectivity. In this Account, we highlight recent advances in prepn., characterization, and catalytic performance of SACs, with a focus on single atoms anchored to metal oxides, metal surfaces, and graphene. We discuss exptl. and theor. studies for a variety of reactions, including oxidn., water gas shift, and hydrogenation. We describe advances in understanding the spatial arrangements and electronic properties of single atoms, as well as their interactions with the support. Single metal atoms on support surfaces provide a unique opportunity to tune active sites and optimize the activity, selectivity, and stability of heterogeneous catalysts, offering the potential for applications in a variety of industrial chem. reactions.

Single-atom catalysis has arguably become the most active new frontier in heterogeneous catalysis. Aided by recent advances in practical synthetic methodologies, characterization techniques and computational modeling, we now have a large no. of single-atom catalysts (SACs) that exhibit distinctive performances for a wide variety of chem. reactions. This Perspective summarizes recent exptl. and computational efforts aimed at understanding the bonding in SACs and how this relates to catalytic performance. The examples described here illustrate the utility of SACs in a broad scope of industrially important reactions and highlight the advantages these catalysts have over those presently used. SACs have well-defined active centers, such that unique opportunities exist for the rational design of new catalysts with high activities, selectivities and stabilities. Indeed, given a certain practical application, we can often design a suitable SAC; thus, the field has developed very rapidly and afforded promising catalyst leads. Moreover, the control we have over certain SAC structures paves the way for designing base metal catalysts with the activities of noble metal catalysts. It appears that we are entering a new era of heterogeneous catalysis in which we have control over well-dispersed single-atom active sites whose properties we can readily tune.

Facile dissocn. of reactants and weak binding of intermediates are key requirements for efficient and selective catalysis. However, these two variables are intimately linked in a way that does not generally allow the optimization of both properties simultaneously. By using desorption measurements in combination with high-resoln. scanning tunneling microscopy, the authors show that individual, isolated Pd atoms in a Cu surface substantially lower the energy barrier to both hydrogen uptake on and subsequent desorption from the Cu metal surface. This facile hydrogen dissocn. at Pd atom sites and weak binding to Cu allow for very selective hydrogenation of styrene and acetylene as compared with pure Cu or Pd metal alone.

Greiner, M. T.; Jones, T. E.; Beeg, S.; Zwiener, L.; Scherzer, M.; Girgsdies, F.; Piccinin, S.; Armbruester, M.; Knop-Gericke, A.; Schloegl, R.

Alloying provides a means by which to tune a metal catalyst's electronic structure and thus tailor its performance; however, mean-field behavior in metals imposes limits. To access unprecedented catalytic behavior, materials must exhibit emergent properties that are not simply interpolations of the constituent components' properties. Here we show an emergent electronic structure in single-atom alloys, whereby weak wavefunction mixing between minority and majority elements results in a free-atom-like electronic structure on the minority element. This unusual electronic structure alters the minority element's adsorption properties such that the bonding with adsorbates resembles the bonding in mol. metal complexes. We demonstrate this phenomenon with AgCu alloys, dil. in Cu, where the Cu d states are nearly unperturbed from their free-atom state. In situ electron spectroscopy demonstrates that this unusual electronic structure persists in reaction conditions and exhibits a 0.1 eV smaller activation barrier than bulk Cu in methanol reforming. Theory predicts that several other dil. alloys exhibit this phenomenon, which offers a design approach that may lead to alloys with unprecedented catalytic properties.

A review. The development of efficient and cost-effective catalysts to catalyze a wide variety of electrochem. reactions is key to realize the large-scale application of renewable and clean energy technologies. Owing to the max. atom-utilization efficiency and unique electronic and geometric structures, single atom catalysts (SACs) have exhibited superior performance in various catalytic systems. Recently, assembled from the functionalized org. linkers and metal nodes, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with ultrafine porosity have received tremendous attention as precursors or self-sacrificing templates for prepg. porous SACs. Here, the recent advances toward the synthesis strategies for using MOF precursors/templates to construct SACs are systematically summarized with special emphasis on the types of central metal sites. The electrochem. applications of these recently emerged MOF-derived SACs for various energy-conversion processes, such as oxygen redn./evolution reaction (ORR/OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and CO2 redn. reaction (CO2RR), are also discussed and reviewed. Finally, the current challenges and prospects regarding the development of MOF-derived SACs are proposed. [Figure not available: see fulltext.].

Electrocatalysis by atomic catalysts is a major focus of chemical and energy conversion effort. Although transition-metal-based bulk electrocatalysts for electrochemical application on energy conversion processes have been reported frequently, anchoring the stable transition-metal atoms (e.g. nickel and iron) still remains a practical challenge. Here we report a strategy for fabrication of ACs comprising only isolated nickel/iron atoms anchored on graphdiyne. Our findings identify the very narrow size distributions of both nickel (1.23 ÅA) and iron (1.02 ÅA), typical sizes of single-atom nickel and iron. The precision of this method motivates us to develop a general approach in the field of single-atom transition-metal catalysis. Such atomic catalysts have high catalytic activity and stability for hydrogen evolution reactions.

Photochemical solution-phase reactions have been widely applied for the syntheses of nanocrystals. In particular, tuning of the nucleation and growth of solids has been a major area of focus. Here we demonstrate a facile approach to generate atomically dispersed platinum via photochemical reduction of frozen chloroplatinic acid solution using ultraviolet light. Using this iced-photochemical reduction, the aggregation of atoms is prevented, and single atoms are successfully stabilized. The platinum atoms are deposited on various substrates, including mesoporous carbon, graphene, carbon nanotubes, titanium dioxide nanoparticles, and zinc oxide nanowires. The atomically dispersed platinum on mesoporous carbon exhibits efficient catalytic activity for the electrochemical hydrogen evolution reaction, with an overpotential of only 65 mV at a current density of 100 mA cm(-2) and long-time durability (>10 h), superior to state-of-the-art platinum/carbon. This iced-photochemical reduction may be extended to other single atoms, for example gold and silver, as demonstrated in this study.

Surface-supported isolated atoms in single-atom catalysts (SACs) are usually stabilized by diverse defects. The fabrication of high-metal-loading and thermally stable SACs remains a formidable challenge due to the difficulty of creating high densities of underpinning stable defects. Here we report that isolated Pt atoms can be stabilized through a strong covalent metal-support interaction (CMSI) that is not associated with support defects, yielding a high-loading and thermally stable SAC by trapping either the already deposited Pt atoms or the PtO2 units vaporized from nanoparticles during high-temperature calcination. Experimental and computational modeling studies reveal that iron oxide reducibility is crucial to anchor isolated Pt atoms. The resulting high concentrations of single atoms enable specific activities far exceeding those of conventional nanoparticle catalysts. This non defect-stabilization strategy can be extended to non-reducible supports by simply doping with iron oxide, thus paving a new way for constructing high-loading SACs for diverse industrially important catalytic reactions.

The electronic structure of transition metal oxides governs the catalysis of many central reactions for energy storage applications such as oxygen electrocatalysis. Here we exploit the versatility of the perovskite structure to search for oxide catalysts that are both active and stable. We report double perovskites (Ln0.5Ba0.5)CoO(3-δ) (Ln=Pr, Sm, Gd and Ho) as a family of highly active catalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction upon water oxidation in alkaline solution. These double perovskites are stable unlike pseudocubic perovskites with comparable activities such as Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O(3-δ) which readily amorphize during the oxygen evolution reaction. The high activity and stability of these double perovskites can be explained by having the O p-band centre neither too close nor too far from the Fermi level, which is computed from ab initio studies.

Organometallic complexes with metal-N/C (M-N/C) coordination are the most important alternatives to precious metal catalysts for O redn. and evolution reactions (ORR and OER) in energy conversion devices. We designed and developed a range of mol.-level graphitic C3N4 (g-C3N4) coordinated transition metals (M-C3N4) as a new generation of M-N/C catalysts for these O electrode reactions. As a proof-of-concept example, we conducted theor. evaluation and exptl. validation on a Co-C3N4 catalyst with a desired mol. configuration, which possesses comparable electrocatalytic activity to that of precious metal benchmarks for the ORR and OER in alk. media. The correlation of exptl. and computational results confirms that this high activity originates from the precise M-N2 coordination in the g-C3N4 matrix. The reversible ORR/OER activity trend for a wide variety of M-C3N4 complexes has been constructed to provide guidance for the mol. design of this promising class of catalysts.

A review. The redn. and oxidn. (redox) of transition metals allow storing charge/energy in Li-ion batteries and electrochem. capacitors and play an important role in catalysis of electrochem. reactions, such as oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in fuel cells and metal-air batteries and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in electrolytic cells. In this review, we present and discuss a universal origin of inductive effect assocd. with metal substitution in Ni, Co, Fe, Mn-based complexes, (hydr-)oxides, and lithium intercalation compds. by alignment of the electron levels of metal complex redox with partially filled metal d-state and oxygen p-state of oxides on the abs. energy scale. Increased redox potentials of metal complexes and oxides are shown to correlate with the increased electronegativity of the substituting metal, which results in the enhancement of the ORR/OER activity. Such observations provide new insights into potential strategies to optimize ORR/OER catalytic activity by tuning the redox properties of metal sites.

The pulsed laser fragmentation in liq. (PLFL) process is a promising technique for the synthesis of carbon-based functional materials. In particular, there has been considerable attention on graphene quantum dots (GQDs) derived from multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) by the PLFL process, owing to the low cost and rapid processing time involved. However, a fundamental deep understanding of the formation of GQDs from MWCNTs by PLFL has still not been achieved despite the high demand. In this work, a mechanism for the formation of GQDs from MWCNTs by the PLFL process is reported, through the combination of exptl. and theor. studies. Both the exptl. and computational results demonstrate that the formation of GQDs strongly depends on the pulse laser energy. Both methods demonstrate that the crit. energy point, where a plasma plume is generated on the surface of the MWCNTs, should be precisely maintained to produce GQDs; otherwise, an amorphous carbon structure is favorably formed from the scattered carbons.

Driven by functionality and purity demand for applications of inorg. nanoparticle colloids in optics, biol., and energy, their surface chem. has become a topic of intensive research interest. Consequently, ligand-free colloids are ideal ref. materials for evaluating the effects of surface adsorbates from the initial state for application-oriented nanointegration purposes. After two decades of development, laser synthesis and processing of colloids (LSPC) has emerged as a convenient and scalable technique for the synthesis of ligand-free nanomaterials in sealed environments. In addn. to the high-purity surface of LSPC-generated , other strengths of LSPC include its high throughput, convenience for prepg. alloys or series of doped nanomaterials, and its continuous operation mode, suitable for downstream processing. Unscreened surface charge of LSPC-synthesized colloids is the key to achieving colloidal stability and high affinity to biomols. as well as support materials, thereby enabling the fabrication of bioconjugates and heterogeneous catalysts. Accurate size control of LSPC-synthesized materials ranging from quantum dots to submicrometer spheres and recent upscaling advancement toward the multiple-gram scale are helpful for extending the applicability of LSPC-synthesized nanomaterials to various fields. By discussing key reports on both the fundamentals and the applications related to laser ablation, fragmentation, and melting in liqs., this Article presents a timely and crit. review of this emerging topic.

Graphene quantum dots (GQDs) have attractive properties and potential applications. However, their various applications are limited by a current synthetic method which requires long processing time. Here, we report a facile and remarkably rapid method for prodn. of GQDs exhibiting excellent optoelectronic properties. We employed the pulsed laser ablation (PLA) technique to exfoliate GQDs from multi-wall carbon nanotube (MWCNTs), which can be referred to as a pulsed laser exfoliation (PLE) process. Strikingly, it takes only 6 min to transform all MWCNTs precursors to GQDs by using PLE process. Furthermore, we could selectively produce either GQDs or graphene oxide quantum dots (GOQDs) by simply changing the org. solvents utilized in the PLE processing. The synthesized GQDs show distinct blue photoluminescence (PL) with excellent quantum yield (QY) up to 12% as well as sufficient brightness and resoln. to be suitable for optoelectronic applications. We believe that the PLE process proposed in this work will further open up new routes for the prepn. of different optoelectronic nanomaterials.

Graphene quantum dots (GQDs) prepd. by pulsed laser ablation in liq. (PLAL) process face barriers to commercialization due to their poor optical properties and the use of expensive carbon precursors. In this work, we report a one-step route for the prepn. of N-doped graphene quantum dots (NGQDs) with excellent optical properties using a low-cost carbon precursor. The as-prepd. NGQDs exhibited excellent optical properties and high quantum yield compared to pristine graphene quantum dots (0.8% → 9.1%) due to the presence of the N atoms. A possible recombination mechanism of NGQDs was investigated by time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy. The increase of N atoms incorporated in the GQDs resulted in an increased fraction of the short recombination lifetime from the intrinsic state. We also report a possible mechanism for the formation of the N atoms in the GQDs structure during the PLAL process, which is explained based on the plasma plume, cavitation collapse, and nitrogen precursor decompn. model.

A review on laser ablation in liq. (LAL) has received considerable attention over the last decade, and is gradually becoming an irreplaceable technique to synthesize nanocrystals and fabricate functional nanostructures because it can offer effective solns. to some challenges in the field of nanotechnol. The goal of this review is to offer a comprehensive summary of recent developments of LAL in nanocrystal synthesis and nanostructure fabrication. First, we will introduce the fundamental processes of microsecond, nanosecond, and femtosecond LAL, and how the active species act differently in plasma, cavitation bubbles, and droplets in the different LAL processes. Second, a variety of LAL-based techniques for nanomaterials synthesis and processing are presented, such as elec.-, magnetic-, and temp.-field LAL, as well as electrochem. assisted LAL, pulsed laser deposition in liq., and laser writing of nanopatterns in liq. Third, new progress in LAL-generated nanomaterials is described. Fourth, we emphasize five applications of LAL-generated nanomaterials that have emerged recently in the fields of optics, magnetism, environment, energy, and biomedicine. Finally, we consider the core advantages of LAL, the limitations of LAL and corresponding solns., and the future directions in this promising research area.
